Fun_Fact: Handel once threatened to throw a soprano out of a window for not singing his aria properly.
Music_style: Handel's music combined German, Italian, and English influences, featuring dramatic flair and ornate counterpoint typical of the Baroque period.
Background_history: Born in Germany, Handel moved to England and became a naturalized British citizen. He once engaged in a keyboard duel with Domenico Scarlatti, which ended in a draw, showcasing his exceptional skill as a performer.

Fun_Fact: Bach was imprisoned for an entire month because he insisted on resigning from his job to work for a better employer.
Music_style: Bach was a master of counterpoint, creating complex polyphonic works with intricate harmonies and motivic organization.
Background_history: Bach fathered 20 children and was once jailed for a month for stubbornly seeking a dismissal from a duke's service. This period in jail allowed him to compose prolifically.

Fun_Fact: Known as "The Red Priest" due to his red hair, Vivaldi composed much of his music for an all-female orchestra at an orphanage.
Music_style: Vivaldi perfected the three-movement concerto form and was known for his virtuosic violin compositions and expressive melodies.
Background_history: Nicknamed "The Red Priest" due to his red hair and clerical status, Vivaldi taught at an orphanage for girls, composing hundreds of works for his talented students.

Fun_Fact: Rameau's opera overtures were so innovative that one depicted chaos before the creation of the universe.
Music_style: Rameau was known for his innovative harmonic theories and expressive French Baroque opera compositions.
Background_history: Rameau didn't publish his first opera until age 50, yet he became a leading figure in French music, engaging in heated debates with conservative musicians of his time.

Fun_Fact: Haydn's "Farewell Symphony" included musicians leaving the stage one by one to signal their desire for a vacation.
Music_style: Haydn significantly shaped the classical sonata, symphony, and string quartet forms, known for his wit and inventiveness.
Background_history: Haydn's mischievous nature earned him the nickname "Papa Haydn." He once composed the "Surprise Symphony" to startle drowsy audience members with a sudden loud chord.

Fun_Fact: Salieri taught Beethoven, Schubert, and Liszt, proving he was more than just Mozart's rival.
Music_style: Salieri composed in the classical style, known for his operas and sacred music.
Background_history: Contrary to popular myth, Salieri was not Mozart's bitter rival. In fact, he was a respected teacher who taught Beethoven, Schubert, and Liszt.

Fun_Fact: Known as "The London Bach," he heavily influenced the young Mozart during their time in England.
Music_style: The youngest son of J.S. Bach, he helped develop the classical style, influencing Mozart.
Background_history: Known as the "London Bach," he moved to England and became music master to Queen Charlotte, introducing the piano to London concerts.

Fun_Fact: Mozart could transcribe entire compositions after a single hearing, showcasing his extraordinary memory.
Music_style: Mozart's music epitomizes the Classical era, known for its elegance, clarity, and emotional depth.
Background_history: A child prodigy, Mozart composed his first piece at age 5 and performed for European royalty. He had a remarkable ability to compose entire works in his head before writing them down.

Fun_Fact: Verdi's opera Nabucco became a symbol of Italian unification, with audiences using its famous chorus as a patriotic anthem.
Music_style: Verdi composed dramatic Italian operas with memorable melodies and intense emotions.
Background_history: Verdi's operas often carried political undertones, with "Va, pensiero" from "Nabucco" becoming an unofficial Italian anthem during the country's unification.

Fun_Fact: Wagner designed and built his own opera house in Bayreuth, specifically tailored to his complex works.
Music_style: Wagner revolutionized opera with his concept of "Gesamtkunstwerk" (total work of art), using leitmotifs and continuous music.
Background_history: Wagner built his own opera house, the Bayreuth Festspielhaus, specifically designed to perform his epic "Ring Cycle," a series of four operas totaling about 15 hours.

Fun_Fact: Tchaikovsky conducted the inaugural performance at Carnegie Hall in New York City in 1891.
Music_style: Tchaikovsky combined Russian folk influences with Western classical traditions, creating emotionally expressive music.
Background_history: Tchaikovsky's ballet "The Nutcracker" was initially considered a failure but has since become a beloved holiday tradition worldwide.

Fun_Fact: Chopin disliked public performances so much that he gave only about 30 concerts in his lifetime.
Music_style: Chopin focused on piano compositions, known for his expressive melodies and innovative use of the instrument.
Background_history: Chopin's heart was removed after his death and buried in Warsaw, while his body remains in Paris, symbolizing his divided loyalties to Poland and France.

Fun_Fact: Stravinsky’s The Rite of Spring caused a riot at its 1913 premiere due to its unconventional music and choreography.
Music_style: Stravinsky's style evolved from Russian-influenced primitivism to neoclassicism and serialism.
Background_history: The premiere of Stravinsky's "The Rite of Spring" caused a riot in the audience due to its revolutionary music and choreography.

Fun_Fact: Schoenberg had triskaidekaphobia (fear of the number 13) and died on Friday the 13th.
Music_style: Schoenberg developed the twelve-tone technique, revolutionizing 20th-century music.
Background_history: Schoenberg was also a painter and was part of the Blue Rider group, which included Wassily Kandinsky. His paintings reflect his innovative approach to both visual art and music.

Fun_Fact: Shostakovich kept a packed suitcase by his door, fearing arrest during Stalin's regime.
Music_style: Shostakovich's music combined traditional forms with intense emotions and often hidden political messages.
Background_history: Shostakovich lived under constant fear during Stalin's regime, with his music alternately praised and condemned by Soviet authorities.

Fun_Fact: Bartók was one of the first ethnomusicologists, traveling to remote villages to record and preserve folk music on wax cylinders.
Music_style: Bartók integrated Hungarian folk music with modern techniques, creating a unique 20th-century style.
Background_history: Bartók traveled extensively, recording folk music on wax cylinders. This research deeply influenced his compositions, blending traditional and modern elements.
